section.title: What is the Premises Editor?
section.para: Premises Editor is an Open Source, Eclipse Modeling Facility EMF based editor Software Application Framework for the development of Multi-platform Livestock Information Solutions.

section.title: Project Goals
Functional Overview
section.para: The Premises Editor is used to document animal event histories for farm animal producers and/or livestock infrastructure providers. Premises details, animals and event histories are created, edited, manipulated, and persisted as Premises documents.

section.title: Premises Editor Use Cases
section.para: To best depict what the Premises Editor can do for Tracker users the following section presents a series of Use-Case diagrams. shows core usage requirements for the Premises Editor.
Once the Tracker Desktop and the Premises Editor are installed setup takes less than a minute. Administration use-cases are shown in .
Updating document use-cases are shown in .

Tracker Operators may need to work with large Premises documents. Providing Tracker Operators with the tools to navigate around these large documents has been a major design goal of the Premises Editor. Navigation use-cases are shown in .

As shown in previous use-cases Premises Documents can be created and updated by human operators Premises Editor. To improve efficiency new animals and events can also be added to Premises Documents by using external tag ID readers connected to the Tracker via data communications channels. This is shown in .

section.title: Premises Documents
section.para: Whether it is word processing documents, spreadsheet documents, or presentation documents, today's computer users are most familiar with software applications that create and manipulate documents that describe specific instances of information.

The Premises Editor enables users to create, transform and edit Livestock Premises documents that represent Animal Premises. The attributes of the premises, the animals in the premises and the events associated with these animals are specified in Premises documents.
Premises document files utilize a .premises file extension to distinguish them from other types of files.

section.title: Premises Data Model
section.para: Because all user activity centers around the creation and manipulation of Premises Documents, understanding the structure (called the data model) of Premises documents is the easiest way to learn to use the information management facilities of the Premises Editor.

section.title: Data Model Core Elements
section.para: All Premises documents structurally conform to the Premises Data Model. In the Premises Data Model, a single Premises contains zero or more animals. Each Animal must have at least one but may have more than one (identification) tag. Each Tag must have at least one but may have more than one associated event.
Core elements of the Premises Data Model are shown in .

listitem.para: The core elements of the Premises Model are depicted as the blue rectangles in the figure.
The notation within the elements are the attributes of the element.
The notation between the elements are the relationships of the elements.

section.para:
The following table offers a text explanation of the Element Relationships. Core Elements of the Premises Model
Element Name
Relationship to other Elements
Premises
There is one premises in a document
Animal
A premises can have zero or many animals
Tag
An Animal can have one or many tags
A Premises can have zero or many tags that are unassigned
Event
A Tag can have one or many events

section.title: Data Model Animal Elements
section.para: The Premises Data Model supports multiple Animal types as shown in

section.title: Data Model Event Elements
section.para: The Premises Data Model supports multiple Event types as shown in

section.title: Two Types of Editor
section.para:
Two types of editors are used to manipulate Premises and Animal Documents, Premises Editor and Premises Transaction Editor as shown in . Upcoming Changes
Future versions of this feature may consolidate all functionality into one editor.

figure.title: Choosing a Premises Editor type to Open a Premises Document

listitem.para: The Premises Editor is used for creating, manipulating, navigating and interpreting Premises and Animal Documents.

The Premises Transaction Editor can be used in a similar way to the Premises Editor, but it has additional functionality to support the Readers Feature. Reader Feature
The Readers Feature is an optional Feature that may be installed (called provisioned) by the user. The Readers Feature allows the Tracker Desktop User to control and configure connections to one or more Tag ID Event Readers enabling them to independently add Event Transactions to Premises Documents.

note.para: Both the Premises Editor and the Premises Transaction Editor can be used for bulk event processing. For more information on bulk even processing see .

section.title: Complementary Views
section.para: The Premises Editor is complemented by several Eclipse and Premises Editor Feature Specific views, each giving the user a unique way to view and edit the information in a Premises Document. Selecting information in the Premises Editor will synchronize selections in complementary views as shown in .

The Outline View is synchronized with selections in the Premises Editor and the
Properties View. By selecting an element in the Outline View, that Element is also selected in Premises Editor and it's attributes are visualized in the Properties View.
Premises Editor selections are also synchronized with the Premises specific Animals view and Events views. These two views provide a master-detail view of information in Premises documents.
For more information on master details views see .

note.para: The Tracker Model Editor also supports an advanced element selection and query functionality, for details see Tracker OCL Query Feature.

section.title: Entering Date and Time
section.para:
When manually entering Dates
The Animal BirthDate value is the only Date value that can be set to null by entering the text 0-0-0 in the Properties view or the Animals view.
and DateTime attribute values in Premises documents the following formating patterns are determinative: Format Patterns for Text Entry
Format Pattern Example
yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSSZ 2007-11-12T00:00:00.000-0600
yyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss'.'SSS 2007-11-12T00:00:00.000
yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm:ss 2007-11-12T00:00:00
yyyy-MM-dd'T'HH:mm 2007-11-12T00:00

section.title: Master Detail Views
section.para: A master detail view is one where a master element and its related detail attributes are shown on the same view.

The master element is depicted as a row in a table of other master elements derived from the document. Columns can be rearranged by dragging the column headers to the desired location and master elements in the table can be sorted by clicking on the column header to use as a sort key. Clicking a second time will sort in the opposite direction.

The Detail attributes are depicted within a form. The detail attributes in form may consist of read-write and read-only attributes. The detail attributes are displayed based on the current element row selection in the master table.
A master detail view can be displayed with a horizontal layout as shown in or with a vertical layout as shown in .
Elements displayed in the master table can be filtered as shown in .
Attributes displayed in the detailed form can be filtered to show only basic attributes as shown in .

section.title: Animals View
section.para: is a master detail view of the Animals Elements in the Premise document being edited in the Premises Editor. Selections in the Premises Editor will synchronize downward to selections in the master table of the the Animals view. Selections in the master table of the Animals View will synchronize upward to the Premises Editor and the Outline View.

section.title: Events View
section.para: is a master detail view of the Events Elements in the Premise document being edited in the Premises Editor. Selections in the Premises Editor will synchronize downward to selections in the master table of the the Events view. Selections in the master table of the Events View will synchronize upward to the Premises Editor and the Outline View.

section.title: Bulk Loading New Events and Animals
section.para: Although Premises Editors make it easy to add individual animals and events to Premises Documents, individually adding dozens of animals, or hundreds of events to a Premises is not practical. For bulk loading of animals and events Premises Editors use Animal Document Templates, Tag IdNumber files and event manipulation features to simplify the process.

Like Premises Documents, Animal Document Templates are document files created by Premises Editor Document Creation Wizards. Think of Animal Documents as containing some but not all the information that is in a Premises Document. Specifically a Animal Document is a Premises Document that only contains a single animal. Like an animal in the Premises Document, an Animal Document Template can contain a tag with an associated set of events. Animal Document Templates serve as a way to represent an event or a set of events that can then be applied to one or more specified animals in a Premises Document.

Within a Premises Document you can specify which animals to apply the events contained in the Animal Document Template to, by:
Directly selecting the animal or a set of animals in the Premises Document with mouse selections.
One or more animals in the Premises Document can also be selected with OCL Query operations. See OCL Query Feature for details.
Indirectly selecting an animal or set of animals in the Premises Document from lists of Tag/@idNumbers contained in Tag IdNumber files. See

section.title: Animal Document Templates
section.para: Animal Document Templates are similar to Premises documents accept they use the *.animal extension, contain a default animal, an attached tag, and a set of representative events. Tracker Event manipulation utilities accessible through popup menus allow Animal Document Templates to be used to add various combinations of animals and/or events to specified sets of animals in the Premises Document.

section.title: Tag IdNumber Files
section.para:
Commercial tag readers typically transmit animal id numbers to computers as ASCII encoded characters (For more information on ASCII, see the Wikipedia entry for
ASCII
). Tag Readers send this data to computers over serial communication ports or Bluetooth network connections.
In the Premises Data Model, the Tag id Numbers are represented as Tag/@idNumber attributes.
The generic way to handle serial and/or Bluetooth tag id number transmissions is to setup the receiving computer's communication facility to capture this data as text files. Capture files containing ASCII numbers that are saved with a *.tags extension are identified as Tag IdNumber Files.

To indicate to Premises Editor that the read time of the tags in a Tag IdNumber file is significant, the name of the tag file may be formated to reflect that time. To timestamp a Tag IdNumber file use the formating of yyMMddHHmmss , where
yy is the last two digits of the year, MM is the month, dd is the day of the month,
HH is the hour of the day in 24 hour clock,
mm is the minute of the hour, ss is the second
A Time stamped Tag IdNumber File Name
060409131111.tags
Specifies the date of all Tag/@idNumber reads to have occurred at 2006-04-09T13:11:11.

tip.para: Tag IdNumber Files can also be utilized by the Reader Feature.

section.title: Adding Events to Manually Selecting Animals
Add Events and/or Animals to a List of Animals Specified in a File
section.para:
To add a series of events and/or animals to the Premises as a whole, you will still need to specify which animals to add event to. This can be done indirectly with a Tag IdNumber file. Select a Tag IdNumber file and invoke a popup menu item it.
Right click on the Animal Document Template that contains the list of animal ids which specify the set of animals in the Premises Document that you wish to add events to.
From the popup menu Select 'Tracker' to get the Tracker specific menu.
Select 'Add Template Events to Premises' to bring up a selection window that will allow you to select a Animal Document Template.
Choose an Animal Document Template containing the set of template events and the default animal type you wish to add the file specified animals in the premises.
